data.title: The History of Our College
data.text:
Daniel L. Marsh is inaugurated as the 4th President of Boston University. He would serve in the role for the next 25 years. Marsh was a 1908 graduate of the School of Theology and also held degrees from Northwestern University. He and his wife, Harriet (Truxell) Marsh, took courses at CLA while attending BU as students.

Miriam Gideon graduates from CLA with a degree in music. She goes on to become a composer and the first woman to write a complete synagogue service. She is one of the most recorded female composers of her era.

After two years and four months, a faculty committee completes its general review of CLA degree requirements and revises the curriculum by scrapping the Major and the Minor in favor of “Fields of Concentration” made up of “Principal” and “Related” courses. One faculty member, Professor Emil Carl Wilm, protested that the new curriculum was “weak, apologetic, and largely irrational.”

A group of eight women in the CLA Class of 1927 formed their own sisterhood and named it "Die Esel Verein," which means "The Donkey Club" in German. They created newsletters for each other to keep in touch after graduation. Thanks to Mildred Lewis, one of the members, many copies from 1929 and beyond have been archived.

The "Boston Stump" is highlighted in the BU centennial publication as a structure chosen to be the central hallmark of the new campus. It would be a reproduction of a tower that stood in Boston, England. The tower never came to be, but its mark can be seen above some doorways when entering the CAS building today.

In the midst of a national focus on general education, CLA ceased requiring students to take Greek and Latin. Instead, it revised its program of study to include a required course in English Composition and a requirement that every student demonstrate proficiency in one Foreign Language. The College then continued its “distribution requirement” and proclaimed that “both for self-development and social usefulness every student requires a measure of understanding in three great fields of knowledge.” Students thereby took 12 credits in the field of “Literature and the Arts,” 12 credits in the “Natural Sciences and Mathematics,” and 15 credits in the “Social Sciences.”

Lt. Donald Herbert Vincent (student of Philosophy, CLA’38, GRS '40) served as an Army Air Force navigator assigned to a bomber squadron during World War II. One week after D-Day, his plane was shot down over southern Germany when returning from a raid to its base in Italy. In this photo, he’s standing in the back row, second from the left, with other members of his crew from the “Gawgia Peach.” A small bronze plaque in CAS 402 memorializes his life. Over 8,000 BU faculty, students, and alumni served in the military during World War II, and over 200 paid the ultimate sacrifice like Lt. Vincent. He was survived by his wife, the former Beatrice S. Warner (CLA’37).

A promotional spread for a new building of Arts & Sciences at 725 Commonwealth Avenue appears in the pages of Bostonia. It announces: “The Plan Is Ready: All Young Men and Women, Whether Rich or Poor, of Whatever Race, Creed or Color, Shall Have Their Chance.” The cornerstone would be laid in 1946 and the design for the turrets would change. It would open in September of 1947, weeks behind schedule, and, for nearly a month, faculty competed with the sound of hammers while students juggled their belongings in the absence of installed lockers. But, finally, the College of Liberal Arts had a new home with other academic units on BU’s new Charles River Campus.

Esther A. H. Hopkins graduates from CLA with a degree in Chemistry. She later becomes the first African American woman to graduate from Yale with a Ph.D. She then serves as a biophysicist and research chemist, as well as an attorney for the Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection.

Seiichi Michael Yasutake graduates with a degree in History from CLA. Like tens of thousands of Japanese Americans, Yasutake and his family were uprooted from their home in Ohio by the U.S. government and detained in an internment camp in Idaho after the outbreak of World War II. President Daniel L. Marsh subsequently positioned Boston University to obtain special approval to receive scores of relocated Japanese students into its classes, freeing them from the detainment camps. Yasutake, who spent a year and a half in the detainment camp before being released, initially attended the University of Cincinnati. After FBI interrogation, however, the University of Cincinnati expelled him. He subsequently moved to Boston University, graduated, and went on to become an outspoken Episcopal Priest who worked tirelessly on behalf of political prisoners while laboring for justice, peace, and human rights.

Georgiana Jagiello graduates from CLA with a degree in Biology. She goes on to become the first woman appointed to the Institute of Advanced Study at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign and the first woman appointed to an endowed chair at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. She perfects the technique for in vitro fertilization.

Katherine E. Hilliker (CLA 1913) retires after an impressive 45 years of service as a staff member. She served as the Secretary to the Dean of CLA in that time, supporting the work of three separate deans (Warren, Taylor, and Graham).

The Center for Philosophy & History of Science is founded as an independent research center within Boston University’s College of Arts of Sciences. One of the oldest one centers for philosophy & history of science in North America, the Center’s mission is to build bridges between the humanities and sciences by promoting interdisciplinary research into the historical, philosophical, ethical, and social factors that govern the theory and practice of science.

Caroline J. Chang graduates from CLA. Born and raised in Boston’s Chinatown, she later serves as the first manager of Chinatown’s Little City Hall in Boston and as a civil rights specialist for the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. A co-founder of the Asian Community Development Corporation, she is honored by BU with an Alumni Award in 1997.

George A. Strait graduates with a Bachelor of Arts from CLA. He later joins ABC News and becomes well known for his appearances on World News Tonight with Peter Jennings. In 1987, he broadcasts an award-winning news series from the Soviet Union. He also founds the National Association of Black Journalists.

Alasdair MacIntyre is appointed Dean of CLA. MacIntyre teaches in both the Department of Philosophy and Department of Political Science. He wins the Metcalf Cup & Prize for teaching excellence in 1974. He later teaches at numerous universities, including Duke, Vanderbilt, and Notre Dame. His book After Virtue is one of the most important works of moral and political philosophy in the 20th century.

Hervé Gouraige graduates from CLA with a B.A. in Political Science. Gouraige, born in Haiti, had not learned to speak English until arriving in the U.S. at the age of 12. He also played varsity soccer. After graduating, he spent the next two years on a Rhodes scholarship at Oxford University where he studied philosophy, politics, and economics. He was the second Boston University student to earn a Rhodes scholarship. He later became a civil and criminal litigator/trial lawyer with Sills Cummis & Gross.

Rev. Dr. Lawrence Edward Carter, Sr. graduates from the Graduate School with a PhD. He becomes the founding dean of the Martin Luther King Jr. International Chapel at Morehouse College. During his time at Boston University, he works closely with Martin Luther King and serves as executive director of the Martin Luther King Jr. Afro-American Cultural Center and the associate dean at Marsh Chapel.

Some students of the class of 1970 come to the commencement of 1980 to make up for their cancelled ceremony 10 years before. It was a stormy day and most came braced with rain jackets and umbrellas for the downpour.

Dennis Berkey, professor of mathematics, is appointed dean of CLA and provost of the University. Berkey had won the Metcalf Cup and Prize for teaching in 1978 and served as Chair of the mathematics department. He later served as the President of Worcester Polytechnic Institute.

CAS launches an optional Core Curriculum to introduce students to “classic works in literature and the arts, great ideas in science, and the significant social events of the modern world.” Centered around weekly lectures and small discussion classes, “The Core” introduces students to enduring texts, art, and ideas that help them engage critically with the world.

BU enters into a partnership with the Lowell Observatory in Arizona to operate the Perkins Telescope, which had been used in the 1960s and 70s for groundbreaking research on the properties of dark matter. BU becomes the sole operator of the telescope in 2019.

The CAS Writing Program is founded to help BU undergraduates develop writing and communication skills essential both to their full participation in the intellectual life of the university and to their future personal, professional, and civic lives. Today, the Writing Program offers more than 350 seminars each semester.

Queen Elizabeth II grants Christopher Ricks a knighthood. Sir Christopher, the William M. and Sara B. Warren Professor of the Humanities, joined Boston University 1986. He formerly served as professor of English at Bristol and at Cambridge, and as the Professor of Poetry at Oxford. A renowned literary critic, Sir Christopher has edited the poems of Tennyson and T.S. Eliot, and has written books on Milton, Keats, Beckett, and Bob Dylan. He joins Professor of Biology Hans Kornberg, who was knighted in 1978, as the two Arts & Sciences professors with that distinction.

Bombs explode at the finish line of the Boston Marathon. Among the witnesses, injured, and helpers are many BU students, faculty, and staff. Statistics graduate student Lingzi Lu is killed by the explosion, and a fellowship fund is established in her name.

The BU Center for Computing and Data Science building, nicknamed "The Stack of Books" and "Jenga Building" by students, opens as the new home of the Departments of Computer Science and Mathematics & Statistics. The building is first used to host class in the spring 2023 semester.
